t: I*p am the rose of Sharon, and the lily of the valleys.
As*p the lily among thorns, so is my love among the daughters.
As*p the apple tree among the trees of the wood, so is my beloved among the sons. I sat down under his shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
He*p brought me to the banqueting house, and his banner over me was love.
Stay*p me with flagons, comfort me with apples: for I am sick of love.
His*p left hand is under my head, and his right hand doth embrace me.
I*p charge you, O ye daughters of Jerusalem, by the roes, and by the hinds of the field, that ye stir not up, nor awake my love, till he please.
The*p voice of my beloved! behold, he cometh leaping upon the mountains, skipping upon the hills.
My*p beloved is like a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh forth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.
My*p beloved spake, and said unto me, Rise up, my love, my fair one, and come away.
For,*p lo, the winter is past, the rain is over and gone;
The*p flowers appear on the earth; the time of the singing of birds is come, and the voice of the turtle is heard in our land;
The*p fig tree putteth forth her green figs, and the vines with the tender grape give a good smell. Arise, my love, my fair one, and come away.
O*p my dove, that art in the clefts of the rock, in the secret places of the stairs, let me see thy countenance, let me hear thy voice; for sweet is thy voice, and thy countenance is comely.
Take*p us the foxes, the little foxes, that spoil the vines: for our vines have tender grapes.
My*p beloved is mine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.
Until*p the day break, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.
